template.name: Redis Info
template.description: Monitor Redis health using "redis-cli INFO" data.

item.name: Cache Hit Ratio
item.description: If the cache hit ratio is lower than ~0.8 then a significant amount of the requested keys are evicted, expired, or do not exist at all. It is crucial to watch this metric while using Redis as a cache. Lower cache hit ratio results in larger latency as most of the requests are fetching data from the disk. It indicates that you need to increase the size of Redis cache to improve your application’s performance.

item.name: Used Memory Ratio
item.description: If the ratio of ‘memory_rss’ to ‘memory_used’ is greater than ~1.5, then it signifies memory fragmentation. The fragmented memory can be recovered by restarting the server.

trigger.name: Redis Evicted Keys
trigger.description: Redis supports various eviction policies that are used by the server when memory usage hits the max limit. A persistent positive value of this metric is an indication that you need to scale the memory up.

trigger.name: Redis Low Cache Hit Ratio
trigger.description: If the cache hit ratio is lower than ~0.8 then a significant amount of the requested keys are evicted, expired, or do not exist at all. It is crucial to watch this metric while using Redis as a cache. Lower cache hit ratio results in larger latency as most of the requests are fetching data from the disk. It indicates that you need to increase the size of Redis cache to improve your application’s performance.

trigger.name: Redis Memory Fragmentation
trigger.description: If the ratio of ‘memory_rss’ to ‘memory_used’ is greater than ~1.5, then it signifies memory fragmentation. The fragmented memory can be recovered by restarting the server.

trigger.name: Redis Rejected Connections
trigger.description: There should not be rejected connections at all.
